description: This word has appeared in 59 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word stilted has appeared in 59 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 11 in “The Radical Act of Eating With Strangers” by Setareh Baig:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Why Wall Street Is So Worried About ‘Refunding’
description: A routine announcement by the Treasury Department about its borrowing plans has attracted more attention than usual because of the rapid rise in interest rates.
content: Investors have fixated this week on a routine quarterly announcement of how the government plans to finance itself, a sign of how sensitive Wall Street has become to a rapid run-up in interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: ‘The Embodiment of White Christian Nationalism in a Tailored Suit’
description: Mike Johnson’s ascension reflects the strength of white evangelical voters’ influence on the House Republican caucus.
content: Mike Johnson is the first person to become speaker of the House who can be fairly described as a Christian nationalist, a major development in American history in and of itself. Equally important, however, his ascension reflects the strength of white evangelical voters’ influence in the House Republican caucus, voters who are determined to use the power of government to roll back the civil rights, women’s rights and sexual revolutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Augusto Higa Oshiro and translated by Jennifer Shyue
title: Read Your Way Through Lima
description: Lima is a city of contrasts and contradictions — gray and tropical, dense and isolated. Augusto Higa Oshiro, one of its writers, recommended books and authors that have captured its complexity.
content: When I was born, in 1946, Lima was home to 640,000 people. Now, as I’m about to turn 77 in the year 2023, Lima is a city of 10 million. The population has grown more than 15-fold. In some ways, you could say that I’ve survived alongside the city. I’ve gotten to know all 43 of its districts and municipalities, and I can say with true pride that I’ve suffered but also delighted in this gray, sleepy city. As Herman Melville describes it, in “Moby Dick”:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattia Ferraresi
title: Italy’s Prime Minister Broke Up With Her Boyfriend. It’s Actually Quite a Big Deal.
description: Giorgia Meloni’s breakup offers a window onto the nature of power in Italy today.
content: Giorgia Meloni broke the glass ceiling again. After becoming the first woman and the first post-fascist leader to be prime minister of Italy, she recently became the first head of government to announce on social media that she had dumped her boyfriend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: A ‘Big Whack’ Formed the Moon and Left Traces Deep in Earth, a Study Suggests
description: Two enormous blobs deep inside Earth could be remnants of the birth of the moon.
content: Where did the moon come from? The most popular theory says that about 4.5 billion years ago, a Mars-size protoplanet slammed into Earth. Some of the resulting debris, tossed into orbit, coalesced to form the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hala Alyan and Vishakha Darbha
title: If Palestinian Freedom Makes You Uneasy, Ask Yourself Why
description: ‘I am undone by empathy’: A Palestinian poet on the fight to exist.
content: “Every time I was told I’d humanized the Palestinians, I would have to suppress the question it invoked: What had they been before?” says the poet, psychologist and professor Hala Alyan, reflecting on her experiences as a Palestinian American. In this audio essay, Dr. Alyan documents how being Palestinian in America is an exercise in auditioning for empathy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Weber
title: Bobby Knight, Basketball Coach Known for Trophies and Tantrums, Dies at 83
description: Knight raised Indiana to the national top tier while upholding academic standards, but he was notorious for the rage he directed at players and referees.
content: Bobby Knight, one of college basketball’s signature coaches and a singular personality renowned for his tempestuousness and hubris, qualities that helped bring him to the pinnacle of his sport and also tainted his success, died on Wednesday at his home in Bloomington, Ind. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: An Old Fashioned With … Brandy? This Must Be Wisconsin.
description: Two state legislators want to declare this the state cocktail. “I’ve had a couple of calls from people: ‘Don’t you have more important work to do?’” one said.
content: So you’re at a classy party and you approach the bartender. You adjust your tie and ask for an old-fashioned. The charismatic bartender smiles knowingly and reaches for his finest bourbon. But no, you interrupt. You’d like it with brandy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: It’s a Bird. It’s a Dame. It’s Heidi Klum’s Halloween Costume.
description: The model and television host dressed as a giant peacock with some help from Cirque du Soleil.
content: Heidi Klum spread her wings this Halloween. Well, technically, several Cirque du Soleil acrobats spread them for her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel Confirms Deaths of 15 Soldiers in Ground Invasion of Gaza
description: The soldiers’ deaths were the first publicly confirmed by the Israeli military inside Gaza since an invasion began on Friday.
content: At least 15 Israeli soldiers have been killed in battles in northern Gaza since Tuesday as its forces press deeper into the enclave, attacking dozens of targets affiliated with its Hamas rulers, the Israeli military said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Searching for Brian Friel, and His Mythical Ballybeg
description: Irish Repertory Theater’s season-long survey of the playwright’s work prompted our reporter to seek out the Irish town that inspired the imaginary site of so many of his plays.
content: Up a steep and grassy windblown hill, in the top row of what’s known as the new graveyard, the playwright Brian Friel lies buried under a dark, glossy slab etched with an image of a St. Brigid’s cross, a traditional Irish symbol woven from rushes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Fed Could Inadvertently Get Trump Re-Elected. Should It Care?
description: The Fed’s efforts to stay out of partisan politics could end up putting its independence in danger.
content: The names Joe Biden and Donald Trump are scarce on the website of the Federal Reserve. When they do appear in a document, it’s rarely something said or written by a Fed governor or staffer. If the occupant of the White House is mentioned at all, it’s generally as “the president” — a role, not a person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Arnold Diaz, Who Reported on New York’s Swindlers, Is Dead at 74
description: A correspondent for three city TV stations, he became famous for his “Shame on You” segments that investigated consumer fraud and aggressively confronted wrongdoers on camera.
content: Arnold Diaz, a brash investigative reporter at three New York City television stations who brought righteous passion to segments that shamed con artists, business owners, scammers, government bureaucrats and others who ripped off consumers, died on Oct. 24 in Greenwich, Conn. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Tammy Murphy, N.J. Governor’s Wife, Prepares to Run for Menendez’s Seat
description: Ms. Murphy has never held or sought elected office but is in a strong position to take advantage of the scandal swirling around Senator Robert Menendez.
content: Walled off and under renovation for nearly six years, the governor’s wing in New Jersey’s 231-year-old State House reopened in April after a gut rehab that was years overdue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: House Blocks Censure of Tlaib on Charge of Antisemitism
description: A solid bloc of Republicans joined Democrats in refusing to back a move to formally rebuke Representative Rashida Tlaib of Michigan, a far-left Democrat, for her harsh criticism of Israel.
content: The House on Wednesday turned aside a Republican effort to formally reprimand Representative Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan, for her participation in a recent pro-Palestinian protest in which she accused Israel of genocide, as a solid bloc of Republicans joined Democrats to reject the move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Emma Bubola
title: Limited Flight From Gaza Strip Begins, as Israelis Close In on Main City
description: Hundreds of people, including a few Americans, left the besieged territory for Egypt, the first group allowed across the border since the war began.
content: After weeks of waiting, hundreds of people were allowed to leave the besieged Gaza Strip on Wednesday, the first of thousands of foreigners, aid workers and critically wounded patients who were expected to exit in the coming days, as two million increasingly desperate people remained behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Two More Arrests Made Over Destruction of Sycamore Gap Tree
description: More than a month after the tree was mysteriously cut down, the police in Britain said they had arrested two men in their 30s on suspicion of criminal damage.
content: Two men in their 30s were arrested and released on bail on Tuesday in connection with the felling of the Sycamore Gap tree, the latest development in the investigation into who chopped down one of Britain’s most photographed trees, which had stood for two centuries in a dip in Hadrian’s Wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: Taking Off From School to Take In the World
description: Vacationing during the off-season has long been considered a cost-saving boon. But can families with school-aged children take advantage? Should they?
content: For her family vacation next year, Liz Thimm has booked a 10-day trip to Bocas del Toro, Panama, in February. She requested time off from her pharmacist job a year in advance, checked out guidebooks from the library and has shared itinerary ideas with her daughter and son — who are 11 and 9 — to involve them in the planning process. One thing she has not and will not do? Schedule the trip around a school vacation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: What Fed Rates Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
description: Savers benefit from higher rates, but borrowers have faced bigger bills on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
content: Policymakers at the Federal Reserve will announce their latest decision on interest rates on Wednesday, and although they are expected to keep rates steady, their assessment of the economy often moves markets, with implications for borrowers and savers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Why Pharmacy Workers at CVS and Walgreens Are Protesting
description: The actions coincided with a period of increasing labor activism by workers in other sectors, including the auto industry and Hollywood.
content: Some pharmacy workers are calling in sick or walking off the job this week to protest what they call inadequate staffing and increasing work requirements, according to protest organizers, and say it’s harder to do their jobs safely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: A Record 119,300 New York City Students Were Homeless Last Year
description: Tens of thousands of migrant children have enrolled in public schools, but many of them do not have a consistent place to live.
content: The number of homeless public school students in New York City reached an all-time high of 119,320 last school year, according to new data released Wednesday, as migrants crossing the southern border continued to flock to the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Man Who Stormed Capitol as Princeton Student Gets 2-Month Prison Term
description: Larry Giberson was a sophomore studying political science when he joined the riot in Washington on Jan. 6, 2021.
content: A 22-year-old New Jersey man was sentenced to two months in prison on Wednesday for taking part, as a Princeton University student, in the storming of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, by a mob loyal to former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Ian Stewart, Allison Benedikt, Jessica Metzger and Dan Powell
title: The Battle Over Aid to Israel
description: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Lulu Garcia-Navarro and Times journalists on the ground.
content: The battle over aid to Israel continues to heat up in Washington. While President Biden has proposed a $105 billion package that would distribute aid to Israel, Ukraine and other corners of the world, Mike Johnson, the newly-elected Republican House Speaker, has put forth a package that only addresses aid to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Nathalia Angarita
title: Drought Saps the Panama Canal, Disrupting Global Trade
description: The number of ships that can travel through the vital route has fallen sharply this year because of a lack of water for the locks, raising costs and slowing deliveries.
content: For over a century, the Panama Canal has provided a convenient way for ships to move between the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, helping to speed up international trade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douwe Dijkstra
title: What Happens When You Reach Out to Your Neighbor?
description: Through reconstructions in a special effects studio, “Neighbour Abdi” embarks on a candid journey through Abdiwahab Ali’s personal history scarred by war.
content: After working on several projects that took me far from home — literally and thematically — I felt a strong need to create closer to home. Across the hall, in the building where I rent my studio, Abdiwahab (Abdi) Ali, a furniture designer and social worker, set up shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in November
description: The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame ceremony will be live-streamed, and “Julia,” “Fargo” and more return. “The Buccaneers” is among the new series out this month.
content: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of November’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: One of the Touchiest Housing Decisions: Do We Stay or Do We Go?
description: Often, one half of a senior couple wants to remain in the house they long loved, while the other half sees their future unfolding in a continuing care community.
content: There are 39 steps from the spot Gerry Goldsholle and his wife, Myra Levenson, park the car at their four-level wood frame house in Mill Valley, Calif., to where, at the end of each evening, they park themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Megan Specia
title: Global Leaders Warn A.I. Could Cause ‘Catastrophic’ Harm
description: At a U.K. summit, 28 governments, including China and the U.S., signed a declaration agreeing to cooperate on evaluating the risks of artificial intelligence.
content: In 1950, Alan Turing, the gifted British mathematician and code-breaker, published an academic paper. His aim, he wrote, was to consider the question, “Can machines think?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Acapulco Saw the Future of Hurricanes: More Sudden and Furious
description: Otis intensified more drastically than all but one other eastern Pacific storm.
content: As of last Monday night in Acapulco, Mexico, no formal hurricane warning had been issued for what would become, barely a day later, the first Category 5 storm ever to make landfall on the Pacific Coast of North or South America.
source.name: The New York Times
